#COVID19 is a serious threat. It demands a response guided by science and scientists. It requires our leaders to step up and take responsibility. It reminds us to stay humble, to be compassionate, and to never give up because lives are on the line. That is how we win. (end/)

Reminder: a safe reopening requires 5 elements a) sustained reduction in cases, b) expanded testing c) tracing and quarantine capacity, d) adequate PPE and hospital surge capacity, e) clear guidelines for people and organizations. We're still falling short in these areas. (10/)

In moments of confusion and chaos when the stakes are high, we need a clear, authoritative voice to guide us. A voice that reflects the best possible knowledge and science we have. That has traditionally been the CDC and its trusted scientists. (8/)

Having worked with many capable scientists and physicians in the CDC, I know they have the skill, experience, and dedication to take on these tough issues. But I am worried they are not being allowed to do so for political reasons. That is deeply concerning. (8/)
Unfortunately, the CDC guidance issued this week after being filtered through the White House was vague on the key questions on most on people‚Äôs minds. (7/)

Fourth, if we count how many employees are either high risk (older, high blood pressure, diabetes, obesity, etc) or live with someone who is high risk, this would be many if not most of our workers. Realistically, how do we protect the vulnerable per CDC but still open up? (6/)

Third, if our state/county says it‚Äôs safe to open but our community doesn‚Äôt meet the previous CDC / White House criteria of having sustained reduction in new cases and adequate testing and contact tracing capacity, should we still open? (5/)

Second, what if someone in our org tests positive? Do we shut down school, our office, or the entire league? Do we have to trace their contacts, especially if our local health department doesn‚Äôt have sufficient capacity to do so - like most departments around the country? (4/)

Some of them are getting quotes of $120-$150/test. If you have 25 employees and you test once per week, that can cost you $15,000 a month. That can be crippling to a small business in a struggling economy. (3/)

First, should we be testing our employees especially given that nearly half of infected people are asymptomatic?  Many feel they should test, but they aren‚Äôt sure how often to test, how and where to get testing, or whether they can afford to do it. (2/)

In the last few weeks, I‚Äôve spoken with large and small businesses, sports teams, universities, and non-profits about their approach to reopening during #COVID19. There is widespread confusion about how to reopen safely.  Here are some of their big concerns: (1/)

My favorite part of Range by @DavidEpstein was the chapter on "Lateral Thinking with Withered Technology" - how Nintendo found creative uses for older technology.

Maybe we need less focus on new technology, and more focus on creative solutions with existing technology.

Hard-to-describe is also harder to pitch. So those with such skills depend more on connections to demonstrate their value. But since most opportunities come through ppl anyhow, this isn't a big issue.

The most valuable skills are often the hardest to describe. 

A skill that fits easily into a degree, certificate or resume, becomes a commodity. Hard-to-define skills are harder to learn, and thus rarer.

Be good at something hard to teach, and you'll never lack opportunities.

Great article by @cdixon https://t.co/5jRS8lPJoi Innovation largely comes from inside-out (large institutions) and outside-in (hobbyists). But these aren't mutually exclusive, and there should probably be more of a connection and dialogue between institutions and hobbyists.
